content.html: I really like the idea of Webmentions and Fediverse interactions, as well as displaying them in my website. However, sometimes I go through an old post and look at the webmentions, click on a few, and get a screaming 404 for all of them. That‚Äôs sad and I absolutely hate having dead links on my website, for I am aware I have too many, including to my own website. What I‚Äôm thinking is to hide webmentions for visitors: they will be visible for me as a logged in user, I always receive a notification when receiving one, so if it‚Äôs a reply, I can always react on it. However, I won‚Äôt display them on my website.

name: Thoughts on Personal Websites and Online Identities
summary: Online services. We all have accounts on those. Be it Instagram, Facebook, Twitter Mastodon, or some other thing that is sucking the life out of us. Even though we are the same physical being behind all of those accounts, we don‚Äôt always come out the same way to all of them. We look different, we sound different. Maybe that‚Äôs the nature of what we post there. They are all online identities.

It reminds me of the time I made a few experiments for fun. I should do that kind of programming again: fun programming. And it doesn‚Äôt necessarily have to be web programming either. Just fun, with fun things.

content.html:
Last weekend, Christiaan and I went to the Christmas Market in Aachen. The first time I went to a Christmas Market was in 2019, in Zurich, during a work trip. Until then, I did not even know that Christmas Markets were a thing. Since moving to The Netherlands, I‚Äôve been wanting to visit one of these magical markets, but, unfortunately, Covid-19 made that impossible. Fortunately, last weekend we made that wish come true.

Traveling to Aachen from Eindhoven was quite straightforward, except for the fact that the railways between Heerlen and Aachen were in maintenance for that weekend only. How lucky! Nevertheless, there were replacement buses from Arriva that brought us to Aachen quickly.

In Aachen, I tried quite a few food items that I‚Äôve never seen before. Namely, reibekuchen ü•î, interestingly shaped, yet amazingly delicious, pancakes ü•û, as well as some flammkuchen üßÖ. All of these foods were very nice, especially enjoyed the pancakes and the flammkuchen.

Of course, among all these food, we also had some gl√ºhwein, both red and white. I have never seen white gl√ºhwein before, but it was quite nice. I also tried eierpunsch, which is quite delicious. I would just turn the notch down on the alcohol amount on that one üòÖ And, finally, we also had some nice hot chocolates.

There were all kinds of things in the market, even though I expected it to be mostly food. That was a pleasant surprise. I bought a few gifts for my parents. I‚Äôm sure my mom would especially love going to a Christmas Market like this. I‚Äôm now in the process of convincing them to come next year around this time. The problem with it is the weather and how cold it is. But, as I told them, as long as it‚Äôs not raining a lot, the cold can be well mitigated with good clothes.

Looking forward for future Christmas Markets üéÑ!

Update: yes, the mugs say 2023 and not 2022. Why? I don‚Äôt know. If you do know, please let me know!

content.html: Programming is always a fun thing. And that‚Äôs what we, developers, do. Sometimes we also write functionalities that we never use, even if we think that we‚Äôre going to selfdogfood them. Some time ago, I added authentication to this website such that anyone with IndieAuth could log in in it. In addition, I added private posts. However, have I ever used them? Basically no. Yes, I have used some private posts in the past but that is not something I have done for a long while. In addition, if I want to share something with someone specific, chances are that we already have some communication channel that is easier to use for both of us other than my website. I‚Äôm now considering removing private posts and login from others than me. Less code to maintain, less vectors of attack and issues. What do you think?
